class_notes:
Modernism, the New Negro Renaissance, the Jazz Age, expatriatism and the arts; gothic and grotesque; magical realism and world-building in literature and the arts. In this course, we'll look at a selection of some of the best novels by 20th century American writers in their efforts to reflect, represent, and transfigure their worlds. 
Texts:  Jean Toomer, Cane (1923); F. Scott Fitzgerald, The Great Gatsby (1925); William Faulkner, The Sound and the Fury (1929); Carson McCullers, The Heart is a Lonely Hunter (1940); Ralph Ellison, Invisible Man (1952); N. Scott Momaday, House Made of Dawn (1968); Toni Morrison, Song of Solomon (1977); Cormac McCarthy, Blood Meridian (1984) and (cheating a little because the author is English and the date of publication is 2001) Neil Gaiman's American Gods (2001). Wait until course meets to buy books. 
Work:  reading, research, papers, midterm, short in-class and out-of-class writing assignments; presentations; attendance policy in effect.
course_description: The development of the modern American novel with representative works by novelists such as Wharton, Dreiser, Hemingway, Faulkner, Fitzgerald, Steinbeck, and Bellow.
